newsitem.title: USA: US Northeast plant outages soften power price fall.
newsitem.headline: US Northeast plant outages soften power price fall.

text.p: Outages at two big New York power plants helped break a hard price fall for Monday bulk electricity in the Northeast, but forecasts for milder weather kept downward pressure on the market, traders said.

Niagara Mohawk Power Corp planned to take its 610 megawatt (MW) Nine Mile Point unit 1 in Scriba, N.Y., later today to repair a leak in the dry well, a Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) spokesman said.

The 650 MW Kintigh coal-fired station, owned and operated by New York State Electric and Gas Co (NYSE&G), remained shut after tripping off line Thursday, market sources said, adding the Barker, N.Y., power plant could resume operation as early as Saturday. NYSE&G declined to comment on the plant's outage.
Although power demand was expected to ease next week after the passage of the arctic cold front, the two plant outages also tightened supply availability, market sources said.
The outages also dried up spot activity with very few trades, especially in the New York market, they said.

Peak, non-firm electricity prices (including transmission costs) for Monday delivery in the eastern New York Power Pool (NYPP) slipped to $30.00-$40.00 a megawatt hour (MWh) from Thursday's $38.00-$44.00.
Off-peak, non-firm power for Monday in eastern NYPP was quoted near $23.00, compared with $22.00-$24.00 Thursday.

Heavy snow squalls was expected to continue to extend through western New York, with wind chills of -15 to -45 degrees Fahrenheit across the region through early Sunday. The Northeast would continue to moderate through the weekend into early next week.
In western NYPP, peak, non-firm power for Monday was pegged at a $35.00-$40.00 versus Thursday's quote near $38.00.
Western NYPP electricity for off-peak, non-firm delivery Monday firmed to $20.00 from Thursday's $16.00-$17.00 range.
In the New England Power Pool (NEPOOL), peak, non-firm electricity for Monday delivery at Northeast Utilities' (NU) border was quoted near $36.00, the lower end of Thursday's $36.00-$41.00 range.
Non-firm, off-peak NEPOOL power for Monday at the NU border was assessed near $25.00, compared with Monday's $22.00-$26.00.
Swing natural gas prices remained strong on this weekend's deep freeze. Spot gas values at the New York City gate held at $6.00-$6.50 per million British thermal units.
